utterances: Ken?

number one pieces of the U.S.
standards for graded shelled nuts?
Jim, but in Iowa, after the precinct caucuses, there is still a county convention to go through, and then a state convention to go through, right?
So there are still two more steps before Iowa names its national convention delegates.
Is that correct?
That's right.
And having gone to this process before, I can tell you that it's not hard to get to the next two stages and go on to the national convention, because it's so much trouble and it's so much expense.
Well, Jim, good luck making your decisions.
Yes.
Bye-bye.
Let's see if we can talk now with - Ken, did you want to…
I was wondering if Jim and the rest of Iowa misses us.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I don't know.
I don't think they miss the advertising.
Yeah.
And I think, you know, I think they can probably park now.
Let's go to Justin(ph).
Justin calling us from Anchorage in Alaska.
Hi there.
Hi.
I was wondering if - well, two questions.
First of all, has it ever happened before that a party has disenfranchised a state the way the Democratic Party did in Florida?
Yes, the week before in Michigan.
Oh, really?
Yes.
Oh, yeah, that's true.
And I was wondering whether the - whether you guys felt that the fact that that contest was for - delegates impacted whether it - the win was worth any momentum.

In other words, going into Super Tuesday, are people going to perceive Hillary Clinton as having gained momentum from that win, or is it going to be kind of null since she didn't win any delegates there?
Let me just also point out the Republicans punished the Republican Florida Party as well.
They got half the delegates they would have gotten ordinarily.
Right.
The 57 delegates that the Republicans were up for grabs in Florida yesterday was half of what they should have gotten, exactly.
But to Justin's question, Ken Rudin, does Hillary Clinton get any bounce from Florida?
Well, she could.
I mean, she certainly won big.
She won basically in two states where they were not campaigning.

I think the argument - the Obama argument - is that in states where he does campaign, he does certainly far better than states where if you just leave it to the polls like Hillary Clinton has been the nominal frontrunner for the longest time.
If you look in California, I think the latest polls I saw is she's up by 12 points, and we still have a week to go before Super Tuesday.
But if Obama campaigns there, if there's a lot of activity there, obviously, that could narrow.
But she does have - look, she does claim it as a victory.
Obviously, she's a nominee.
She's going to insist that Michigan and Florida delegates be seated.
I think, historically, one thing I always think of is 1964, when the all-white Mississippi Democratic Party was challenged by the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party, which is a biracial coalition.
I believe they lost at the time.
But again, it was the first serious attempt I saw at a delegation being thrown out.
And just - we're sure was an oversight, Hillary Clinton did win a contest that was contested, of course, in New Hampshire.
Oh, that's correct.
Absolutely right.
Right.
And Nevada as well.
All right.
Justin, Alaska votes on Super Tuesday.
Who are you going to vote for?
I'm going to be casting - I'm going to be caucusing for Obama.
For Obama.
Yeah.
Okay.
I was an Edwards supporter, but now I'm going towards Obama.
Thanks very much.
Good luck.
Bye-bye.
Bye-bye.
There's no place like home.
Sorry.
Let's get Tyler(ph) on the line.
Tyler with us from San Antonio.
Hi, gentlemen.
Go ahead.
Well, my comment is I could not disagree more with my fellow Southern white Democrats from Florida.
And this is why I'm a first-generation Democrat.
Both of my parents are Evangelical Republicans.
And with all the trouble that the Republicans have been having the past eight years, they have no cause to rally around John McCain, but Hillary is our nominee.
They have every reason to come out and vote for her.
And I was an Edwards supporter.
I'm proud to support Barack Obama.
I guess you could place me in the ABC category - anybody but Clinton.
And you think that Hillary Clinton, as the Democratic nominee, would energize the Republican Party base.
If anybody remembers the '90s, they will understand that all Christian Evangelicals wanted to do was to get rid of Clinton.
And underneath his presidency, we saw her name trashed, his name trashed.
We saw an impeachment.
We saw us lose Congress - we lost the majority the first time that he ran.
The second time, we lost even more.
I just see them galvanizing the loads to come out against her.
Everybody remembers the '90s, Tyler.
Ken and I can't remember the '60s for some reason.
But Ken…
That's because we were there.
Yeah.
Well, look.

There are a lot of Democrats who say that the '90s were a great time for the Democratic Party, and Bill Clinton got things accomplished that the Democrats haven't gotten accomplished in a long, long time, and many Democrats see him, finally.
And of course, if the Evangelicals were so upset with him, they had the opportunity to throw him out of office in 1996, and he won an easy re-election.
But there are - a large segment and, as you know, and I've talked to a lot of people, Democrats who say they just cannot vote for Hillary Clinton.
But she has plenty of time to change minds.
I mean, there were some people who just, you know, like the fellow from…
Florida.
…Florida earlier, who said he could never vote for Barack Obama.
The more you see these candidates, the more you have an opportunity to change.
And so the good news for us political junkies is there's plenty of time to go before a nominee is going to be named.
